]. The protein concentrations of plant extracts were measured as descried by
]. GUS activity was calculated as pmol 4-Methylumbelliferone (4-MU) per min
per microgramprotein. Three replicates were performed for each sample.
Total RNA frommature leaves and mesocarp at five developmental stages were extracted as
described previously, and cDNAs was used for real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR).
) were designed for RT-qPCR. The house-
) was used as an internal control for expression
analysis. RT-qPCR was carried out using a CFX Connect™ Real-Time PCR Detection System
premix Ex Taq™ II (Tli RNaseHPlus) Kit (Takara, Tokyo,
Japan) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Expression was quantified as comparative
]. Reactions were in triplicate including template-
The open reading frame (ORF) cDNA sequence (1362 bp) of a ω-3 fatty acid desaturase (desig-
nucleotide sequence is 100%identity with that from
acid polypeptide with the conserved domain of ω-3 fatty acid desaturase (amino acids 1–443),
which is predicted to be chloroplastic. The protein BLAST analysis of EgFAD8 showed that it
shared high homology (more than 70%) with other members of the ω-3 desaturase enzyme
family. Phylogenetic analysis of EgFAD8 with various fatty acid desaturases frommodel plant
revealed that EgFAD8 clusters with two chloroplastic ω-3 fatty acid desa-
turases AtFAD7 and AtFAD8, as well as the endoplasmic reticulum-type ω-3 fatty acid desa-
in leaf and mesocarp during fruit
in leaf and mesocarp at five different developmental stages
-actin as an internal control. The results showed that the
in mesocarp was quite flat during ripening with a slight increase at
leaves was at least twice that in mescoarp (
The activity of EgFAD8 was determined by heterologous expression in
mented with linoleic acid as substrate, which is absent in yeast. Yeast transformed with empty
vector (pYES2) was used as negative control. The total fatty acid composition of yeast trans-
or pYES2 was detected and analyzed. The result showed that yeast trans-
produced a new fatty acid species 18:3 ω-3 (about 0.27 mol%) in yeast,
but not presented in the negative control (
). Meanwhile, there was no obvious difference
in the levels of other fatty acids between yeast transformed with
